Having a continuing stream of already seen or unseen on-demand digital choices, I try to the best of my abilities to keep up with films of a general genre, which I might be interested in.  This eliminates a lot of genres actually, as I can't stand, in no particular order, horror/slasher films, "masterpiece theater-ish, British soap-operish" borefests, most heavily/quickly subtitled foreign movies (because of my failing eyesight), most westerns, and anything/everything remotely connected with Michael Bay.Genres I generally favor, again in no particular order, are original or ground-breaking works from any time period, comedies and especially romantic comedies, intelligent and well done sci-fi flicks, and compelling and enlightening dramas, either based upon true-life stories or fictional ones.  "The Family Stone" falls into my last category mentioned, that of fictional drama, and with the big name cast and at times fast-moving plot, this passed my 20 or so minute mark of being tolerable.  And so I watched it till the end.  An end which was most satisfying, simply because it WAS the end of a terrible flick which I will never watch again.I have always found it easier to write about films I have a favorable opinion of, whether classic, older movies, or newly discovered studio or independent, more recently produced gems.  It's a lot tougher however, to write about films I've seen which I hated enough to bother trying to warn others with, what I hope will be a helpful review.  This becomes especially difficult when it concerns a film, which engenders in people a sort of love/hate view.  To cut to the chase of this review, I really hated this movie, and generally, here's why...This is well cast with several big names and lesser knowns, most of which have been involved with much better works than this, which is one of the reasons I was drawn to watch it in the first place, and which I suspect, a lot of others were and are and will be.  However, while all seem to give it a good effort, nothing can overcome, for me at least, the unbelievable characters (all of whom resemble no real human beings I've ever encountered), and the draw-by-numbers, unbelievable at every turn script and writing.  It all starts out promising, the whole premise, the genre, the cast, and it is all done with very professional, technical quality and generally unobtrusive direction, but early on I was scratching my brain at why I should feel the least bit empathetic with the "family" and its various components.  Which is what the film and the film's creators apparently want viewers to take away from all of this.  In that respect, this is a miserable misfire.The "tagline" of this film upon its release was "Feel The Love."  How ironic because the "FAMILY STONE" the supposedly "uptight, conservative" Sarah Jessica Parker meets up with when her fiancé coaxes her to an Xmas visit to HIS folks's home, seemed to me nothing more than a bunch of unlikable, "neo-liberal," reactionary, upper middle class, intolerant, politically correct to the point of nausea, snobbish morons.Politically, I consider myself far, far to the left, but this movie really distorts generally held ideas of the "left" and "liberal" leaning folks out there, and does a real disservice to both.  The "working title" for this production was called "Hating Her."  The "her" obviously being Ms. Parker's character, "Meredith Morton."  Yet, this whole premise is why the film fails.  Because Meredith's character is really not political at all, but just a lazy, convenient poor-scriptwriting miscreant, one of whose major SINS against "the family" seems to be her habit of clearing her throat when nervous!  Great reason to hate her!  Or her raising misguided but civil, honest issues at the holiday dinner table, where she is ridiculously crucified for it.  Up to and including the end, I felt so much more sympathy for her than the B-word mother (Keaton) who supposedly suffers and eventually dies (but by then, I almost cheered).  Bad writing, bad, bad, bad writing.First, there really is no establishing development of Meredith's character except for a few surface features, none of which are important or revealing.  Second, given this, there is no real establishing development of the "family" and its dynamics and conflicts, let alone any believable explanation of their rather mean-spirited and hateful "eccentricities."  Third, the filmmakers seem throughout till the very pretentious end, are asking the viewer to NOT identify with a likeable villain, Sarah, and IDENTIFY with a truly unlikable group, the family.  It all eventually makes no sense at all.Throughout, my main continuing thought was from the beginning, WHY exactly does most of the "family" here HATE "HER?"  In fact, if anything, after the requisite 15-20 minutes, I found myself asking, why in the world would Sarah Jessica Parker's character want ANYTHING to do with this family of creeps?  Absurdly, various reasons are thrown about for the family character's "hateful" and contrived "behaviors," but by the film's completely over-the-top, sappy, totally illogical and pandering finish, it was all too late.  The way all of this resolves, with double one-night stands replacing seemingly established character involvements all just adds to the mess this movie is, from beginning to end.A really, really, really bad movie.  Spend a couple of hours of your movie-viewing life on better than this junk.  It's hard really to fit this into any genre, though it tries to alternately switch between comedy, drama, and romance.  The only genre I will consign this to for future reference is that of really, really, really bad movies, which does its cast and production values a real shame.
summary: Worst movie I've recently seen till the bitter end...

reviewText: I laughed and winced in recognition all through this movie. The engaged couple, Meredith (Sarah Jessica Parker) and Everett (Dermot Mulroney) are the oldest children of their respective families. They're the successful high achievers of the family, but they're also wound very tight and very anxious about how others are reacting to them. As a first child I know all about the pressure to be perfect all the time, yet then judged for being too perfect! As the saying goes, a halo only has to slip 9 inches to become a noose . . .I was pretty sure that the movie was going to be about how they learn to relax, be themselves, and let others in. But the movie's deeper than that. While Meredith gets attacked repeatedly for her uptightness, eventually she does something that is, in fact, perfect - she gives a gift to the family that is exactly what they need. The only person who doesn't realize it is Meredith.The cast is uniformly good. Luke Wilson mostly played Luke Wilson, but in one scene made me cry. Dermot's just been a pretty face to me before, but he also had some good moments. Sarah Jessica Parker is perfect, and Diane Keaton and Craig T. Nelson are wonderful as the parents who aren't quite as perfect as they'd like to believe they are. reviewText: Sarah Jessica Parker plays Meredith an uptight, conservative businesswoman. Meredith is invited to the home of her boyfriend Everett (Dermot Mulroney) for the Christmas holidays, but his family (the Stones ... subtle naming, isn't it?) consists of mostly unconventional and eccentric members. So what happens in their annual celebration?Now, don't get me wrong. I know the eccentricity in characters can be fun. However, to be eccentric for the Stones means, if I may borrow another reviewer's word, to be judgmental. Many of the Stones behave in a palpably cold and detached way towards Meredith (and some even before they meet her).Please tell me, what should I feel when Everett's mom is not nice to her, and she is played by usually charming and lovely Diane Keaton? And what should I do when not only Everett's gay brother is unkind to her, but his sister (Rachel McAdams) is so mean and cruel to Meredith, who is only trying to be polite? AND we are supposed to smile at whatever the Stones say and do, including two paper thin characters - Luke Wilson as hippie like brother and Craig T Nelson whose character as daddy is totally unmemorable? I think I am a pretty attentive person, but as far as I can remember, I have never discerned a single moment that rings true in the film.And Meredith, who is supposed to be working as 'a career woman,' behaves very atrociously before the Stones at dinner, unnecessarily referring to the family member's sexuality and ethnicity. This manipulative scene (which includes crying Diane Keaton throwing fork) might be intended to be funny or insightful, but it only shows that the director does not know we normally do not talk in such offensive manners to each other at least during the Christmastime if not on the internet.To me the only person who really looks like a human (I mean, real human) is Clare Danes who plays the more laid-back sister of Meredith. But even she is subject to some uninspired direction (like falling from a bus like Buster Keaton .. I mean it) plus one conventional plot device called `I got a new boy/girlfriend' at the film's neat and mawkish ending.OK, I know. Any familiar plot can be forgiven. Most comedies or romances are based on familiar settings, and the results are often pleasant. `The Family Stone' is NOT that pleasant, however, full of unbelievable behaviors from annoying people. The film ends with a neat and sappy conclusion, but that only worsens the incredibly bad writing of the whole film which also includes a person with terminal disease. Oh, please. Not again.
summary: I Tried To Like Them, But The Stones Here Are Hard To Believe

reviewText: Diane Keaton is the empitome of naturalism; not the sort of naturalism where an illusion of how people really do sound and seem is acheived so much as everything on top of such surface behavior, the sort of humanity we keep within our own homes; the mannerisms we're perhaps too ashamed to let free in public, those little idiosyncrasies that only family are so privalaged to see. In emanating this realism, every moment of her performance as Sybil Stone feels utterly convincing. She swears in front of her family, she inhibits none of her opinions, and she seems to embrace her son Ben's tendencies towards pot and nudity as endearing quirks rather than moral corruption. Keaton made me love her from the first devastating frames of Sybil looking at what may end up being her final Christmas tree, the little bits of family she cherishes in spite of what some may label as dysfunction, or what I would label as normalities.Keaton, however, may be the biggest redeeming factor of "The Family Stone," a somewhat lovable but often weak holiday ensemble dramedy. Its tonal imbalance threatens to undermine what humanity there is. Since family comedies are more commonly delivered in the form of sophomoric romps like Meet the Fockers, this "humanity" is something to appreciate, no matter if it comes in broad patches without ever being stitched together. The realism may be responsible for the prior buzz calling Stone "intelligent." Sure, it's mildly intelligent and grasps family dynamics with considerable strength, yet there's too much slapstick and even too much cruelty to consider "The Family Stone" anything revelatory.None of the actors, though, have anything to do with holding the film back. They are its source of warmth; particularly Keaton and Luke Wilson, the latter of whom really proves himself to be a great presence in the film. The ensemble digs deep for the intelligence and brings it to the surface often making what could have been ridiculous (Wilson's "I was the snow" monologue, for instance) effective in reflecting the ways we often express ourselves in hopefully profound but entirely silly metaphors. What's even more commendable is the fact that one of the more unknown actors (Elizabeth Reaser as Susannah Stone) offers one of the film's most reliant points of solace. Her Susannah encompasses all the qualities of a young mother, offering the calm of understanding at all points.Surprisingly, the film's flaws arrive as soon as Sarah Jessica Parker hits the screen. I love her to death ("Sex and the City" is one of my favorites) and I'll make the firm point that she does a fine job. The problems just cannot be attributed to her but instead to Thomas Bezucha's screenplay. As previously mentioned, it's hailed by the film's fans as thoroughly intelligent, but Parker is given a caricature to work with, a person who simply changes as any prototypical uptight fiance-meeting-the-family inevitably does: first the hair's up, then it's down with beautiful flow and relaxation. Parker does a great job making Meredith more plausible than the screenplay allows. Her greatest achievement is maintaining audience sympathy when she makes a point to Sybil about raising gay children in the absolute worst way.But therein lies the problem: Parker has to fight too hard against the irritating qualities inherent in her character as well as the cruelties of the Stone family, which is relentlessly judgmental. Perhaps the family's protectiveness over Everett, the son engaged to Meredith, would've been understandable had there not been so much slapstick (a paradoxical tone that is never well balanced). Bezucha's use of comedy is rather pedestrian and only cheapens the drama, regardless of whether or not the comedy is funny. Ultimately, The Family Stone could have been better with a stronger director capable of handling the contradictory tone (dramedies are possible, but most certainly difficult). At least Bezucha manages to capture some humanity and some warmth, and the performances are stellar. Its most positive aspect is contradicting the expectations of a "dysfunctional" family, a claim that bothered me going into the film. If this family is dysfunctional, what family is functional? Like Sybil, Bezucha embraces each character's characteristic flaws and demonstrates the unique bond of a family: you can't choose who they are, so you learn to love each other for your differences and eccentricities. The imperfection is what makes this bond stronger. Above all else, Bezucha understands this, and maybe that's most important.
